issues.description: The problem statement and UML specify an addGuestStudents(int) method (single int parameter). The template, however, provides a different signature: addGuestStudents(int, boolean). The solution implements the expected single-argument method. This mismatch in method parameters in the template will confuse students about which signature to implement and may cause compilation/test failures if automated tests expect addGuestStudents(int).
issues.suggested_fix: Change the template method signature to match the specification and solution: replace public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents, boolean validateInput) with public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents). If input validation is desired for teaching purposes, either implement it inside the single-argument method or provide an overloaded private/helper method; do not expose a different public signature than the one specified in the problem/UML.

issues.description: The template implementation of addGuestStudents declares a different method signature than the problem statement and the solution. The problem statement and UML specify addGuestStudents(int) (single int parameter) but the template provides addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents, boolean validateInput) (an extra boolean parameter). This mismatch can confuse students about the intended API and what to implement: they may follow the template signature or the UML, creating unnecessary cognitive load and potential compile/run mismatches with tests or the provided solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the template method signature with the problem statement and solution by changing the template to: public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents) { ... }. If the boolean validateInput parameter was intentionally required for input validation, update the problem statement, UML and solution to document and implement that parameter consistently instead.
